title: Railroad Bailouts in the Great Depression. (arXiv:2205.13025v3 [econ.GN] UPDATED)
abstract: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Public Works Administration loaned 46 railroads over $802 million between 1932 and 1939. The government's goal was to decrease the likelihood of bond defaults and increase employment. Bailed-out railroads did not increase profitability or employment. Instead, they reduced leverage. Bailing out a railroad had little effect on its stock price, but it resulted in an increase in its bond prices and reduced the likelihood of a ratings downgrade. However, bailouts did not help railroads avoid defaulting on their debt. We find some evidence that manufacturing firms located close to railroads benefited from the bailouts.

translated_title: 大萧条时期的铁路纾困计划
translated_abstract: 重建金融公司和公共工程管理局在1932年至1939年间向46家铁路公司发放了802多万美元的贷款，政府的目标是减少债券违约的可能性和增加就业。然而被纾困的铁路公司并没有增加盈利或就业，反而减少了杠杆比率。纾困铁路公司对其股票价格几乎没有影响，但导致其债券价格上涨并降低了评级下调的可能性。然而，纾困并没有帮助铁路公司避免债务违约。我们发现，一些位于铁路附近的制造业公司受益于这些纾困计划。
tldr: 大萧条时期，美国政府通过向铁路公司提供贷款来减少债券违约的可能性和增加就业，然而这些纾困计划没有帮助铁路公司增加盈利或就业，而是减少了杠杆比率。纾困对股票价格几乎没有影响，但导致其债券价格上涨并降低了评级下调的可能性。同时，这些纾困计划也没有帮助铁路公司避免债务违约，但有利于一些附近的制造业公司。
en_tdlr: The US government provided loans to 46 railroads between 1932 and 1939 to reduce the likelihood of bond defaults and increase employment during the Great Depression. However, the bailouts did not help increase the profitability or employment of the railroads, but instead reduced leverage. Bailouts had little effect on stock prices, but increased bond prices and reduced the likelihood of a ratings downgrade. The bailouts did not help the railroads avoid debt default, but some nearby manufacturing firms benefited from them.
